data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Introduction to the Theatre 1
data.description: Introductory study of the theatre as a major art form. Selected plays as produced in their historical contexts. Contributions of the actor, designer and technician to theatrical production.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Introduction to the Theatre 2
data.description: An extension of the studies described in 101A.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Introduction to Performance
data.description: This workshop course introduces students to the creative processes of performance in a range of formal and informal settings. Emphasis is placed on the student's development as a performer. Prior performance experience is not required.
data.notes: [Note: Must attend first class. May be subject to priority enrolment.]

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Introduction to the Theatre 1
data.description: Introductory study of the theatre as a major art form. Selected plays as produced in their historical contexts. Contributions of the actor, designer and technician to theatrical production.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Performance Studies
data.description: This workshop course in performance studies explores performance as a way of knowing. It investigates performance as artistic practice and as a means of understanding historical, social and cultural practices, including drama/theatre texts, poetry, narratives and texts of everyday life.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A; Theatre and Performance majors and minors only

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Performing Text
data.description: Students explore techniques to analyze, interpret, and perform texts.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Performing the Body
data.description: Students explore techniques to access and develop the body as a resource for performance.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Technical Production 1
data.description: Students develop basic proficiency in the technical elements of live theatre and performance production, including carpentry, lighting, projection, sound, wardrobe, and properties. Students apply these concepts in a departmental production.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Technical Production 2
data.description: Students develop intermediate proficiency in the technical elements of live theatre and performance production, including carpentry, lighting, projection, sound, wardrobe, and properties. Students apply these concepts in a departmental production.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Performance Creation
data.description: Students study, apply, and critique a range of processes for making theatre and performance, paying close attention to the relationship between the approach to creation and the significance of works in the communities where they are performed.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Production Participation 3
data.description: Students work at an intermediate level with faculty, staff, and visiting artists to explore and increase proficiency in specific areas of performance creation. Areas include research, conception, writing, direction, design, performance, production, stage management, production management, publicity, dramaturgy, critique, and documentation.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Production Participation 4
data.description: Students work at an intermediate level with faculty, staff, and visiting artists to explore and increase proficiency in specific areas of performance creation. Areas include research, conception, writing, direction, design, performance, production, stage management, production management, publicity, dramaturgy, critique, and documentation.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: English Drama to 1642
data.description: The Middle Ages, the Elizabethans and Jacobeans (excluding Shakespeare), and the Spanish Golden Age.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Survey of Dramatic Literature and Theory 5
data.description: The first part of the 20th century.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Survey of Dramatic Literature and Theory 6
data.description: The second part of the 20th century.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Musical Theatre and Musical Film
data.description: The course explores the elements that are unique to the musical, and the translation of this essentially artificial art form into theatrical and cinematic versions. It will examine in particular the distinctions between musicals based on stage productions and musicals devised exclusively for film.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Tennessee Williams in Performance
data.description: This course focuses on a major dramatist. It will consider first of all the times, the life and the work. It will then concentrate on productions of plays in various media, and include interpretations, design styles, critical reception and related topics.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Beckett in Performance
data.description: This course focuses on the various ways in which the dramatic works of Samuel Beckett have been rendered in performance.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3A Drama majors only

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Approaches to Acting with Text
data.description: Students apply conceptual and theoretical approaches to acting in traditions emphasizing the text as a resource for performance.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Approaches to Acting with the Body
data.description: Students apply conceptual and theoretical approaches to performance in traditions emphasizing the body as a resource for performance.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Performing the Voice
data.description: Students explore techniques to access and develop the voice as a resource for performance.
data.prerequisites: DRAMA 102/SPCOM 102; one of DRAMA 221, DRAMA 222, SPCOM 223; Level at least 3A

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Design Theory and Practice
data.description: Students apply conceptual and theoretical approaches to design in the areas of set/space, light, projection, and costume.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Costume Design
data.description: This course examines the art form and practical craft of costume design for the theatre as it is practiced today. All aspects of the design and construction of stage costuming are addressed, with emphasis on text analysis, capturing a period look, fabric choice and methods of costume construction, and rendering approaches and techniques.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A Drama or Fine Arts students

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: History of Costume
data.description: This course surveys the development of costume, focusing primarily on fashionable clothing in Western societies from the Renaissance to today. It examines the influence of art and design movements, social roles and trends, and manufacturing and marketing methods on the changing fashionable style image of men and women. It includes the role of the fashion designer as well as theatrical and film costume design.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3A Drama majors only

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Lighting Design for the Theatre 1
data.description: An introduction to the theory and practice of theatre lighting design through studio experience.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Stage Management
data.description: Students explore approaches to stage management for theatre and performance.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Writing for Performance
data.description: Students explore techniques for analyzing, interpreting, and creating texts for theatre and performance.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Central and East European Film
data.description: Examination of the development of the motion picture art in Central and Eastern Europe after World War II. Selected work of prominent directors of the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, the former USSR, and former Yugoslavia will be discussed (Chytilova, Forman, Jancso, Makavejev, Tarkovsky, Wajda, and others). Film screenings.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Film and Television 1
data.description: Examination of principles of the audiovisual language and the main structural elements of the cinematic work. Discussion of the relationship between film, television and other arts/media. Film screenings.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Film and Television 2
data.description: Development of critical judgment and expression in the area of film and television. Investigation of the role of motion pictures and TV in society. Review of major theories (Eisenstein, Bazin, Metz, Kracauer, Esslin). Film screenings.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Approaches to Directing
data.description: Exploration of the director's task in its practical, theoretical and historical aspects.
data.prerequisites: DRAMA 101A/200, 243, 244. Theatre and Performance students only

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Directing 2
data.description: Students will be expected to form their own production company, mount a short play, and submit a detailed promptbook.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Stage Combat
data.description: The basics of physical contact for the stage, with a strong emphasis on safety considerations. Hand-to-hand combat and work with a variety of weapons including foils are covered. In addition, aspects of fight choreography are explored, as well as falls and pratfalls.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Theatre History 1
data.description: Theatre history from Classical Greece to the Renaissance.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Theatre History 2
data.description: Theatre history from the Classical French and English Restoration periods to the present era.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Canadian Drama
data.description: This course explores traditions and experiments in Canadian drama through an analysis of Canadian plays, especially those from 1960 to the present, in their historical and theatrical contexts.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Russian Drama before 1905
data.description: A study of the origins and development of Russian drama up to 1905. Reading and critical analysis of major works in various genres with emphasis on authors of the 19th century.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English. This course will have a Slavic language component for students in REES academic plans.]

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Russian Drama after 1905
data.description: A study of the origins and development of Russian drama after 1905. Reading and critical analysis of major works in various genres with emphasis on authors of the 20th century.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English. This course will have a Slavic language component for students in REES academic plans.]

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Shakespeare 1
data.description: A study of the plays written before 1599-1600, excluding Julius Caesar.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Shakespeare 2
data.description: A study of the plays written after 1599-1600, including Julius Caesar.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: American Film
data.description: American Film will examine the relationship between film and the social/political movements of each decade since 1930. In this way, the course will address the medium as both chronicler of history and agent for change and/or conformity. At the same time, attention will be paid to the nature of film, its technical development and the changing approaches to acting in American films that is a direct result of the development in theatre of a specific and distinctive American acting style.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: The New Hollywood
data.description: The course examines the impact of European New Wave films of the late 1950s and early 1960s on American filmmaking, focusing on the revolutionary changes evident during the later 1960s and the 1970s. The course considers the work of filmmakers such as Bogdanovich, Cimino, Coppola, Peckinpah, Penn, Scorsese and others.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Film Noir
data.description: The principal focus will be on the American "noir" films between 1940-55, the period during which the genre itself was defined and developed. Beyond the style and the techniques of this unique world of film, the parallels between cinema noir and America's social and political pressures will be examined. The course will include the neo-Noir school, the filmmakers who 'borrowed' from the originators by re-applying the basics to the changing times in the 1970's and beyond.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Women and Film
data.description: The study of selected film texts is informed by contemporary critical readings in feminist and film theory. Subjects addressed may include representation, fetishism and the gaze, female spectatorship, women's genres (e.g., melodrama, romance), female stereotypes (e.g., the femme fatale) and women's documentary film.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Acting Styles
data.description: Examines American and British acting styles from 1945 - 1965 through a study of representative films. The evolution of contemporary techniques and styles is considered, first by exploring the dominant methods in each country from the mid-century, and then by observing an increasing similarity between the two.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Political Theatre
data.description: Considers the politics of governing, religion, family, marriage, work, race, gender and sexual orientation as they are expressed and commented on in a variety of contemporary, international play texts. Class discussion focuses on both the texts and the society that gave rise to each playwright's passions.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Theories of the Modern Theatre
data.description: An examination of the writings of selected theorists and practitioners of the modern theatre in terms of their contrasting ideas on the kind of expression and communication possible through the medium of theatre. Their works will be studied in relation to each other and to concurrent social, political, and aesthetic developments.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Genre
data.description: A study of the various dramatic genres and sub-genres in terms of their distinguishing characteristics. Selected plays from various periods in theatre history will be examined on the basis of some of the most significant theoretical writings in the field. The usefulness of genre distinctions will be tested against plays/performances which appear to transcend them.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Theatre and the New Media
data.description: The primary objective of this course is to investigate ways in which new media technologies have been, and can be, applied in theatrical practice. It examines the range of opportunities and challenges this synthesis poses and provides students with some of the insights and skills required to apply new media technologies in a theatrical context. On the basis of such practical and theoretical study, students will also engage in projects which explore creatively the coalition between theatre and the new media.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Production Participation 7
data.description: Students work at an advanced, independent level with faculty, staff, and visiting artists to create and reflect upon a major, collaborative performance project. Students engage in all areas of project creation, including research, conception, writing, direction, design, performance, production, stage management, production management, publicity, dramaturgy, critique, and documentation.
data.prerequisites: One of DRAMA 206, 207,306, 307, 316, 317; Theatre and Performance students only.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Production Participation 8
data.description: Students work at an intermediate level with faculty, staff, and visiting artists to explore and increase proficiency in specific areas of performance creation. Areas include research, conception, writing, direction, design, performance, production, stage management, production management, publicity, dramaturgy, critique, and documentation.
data.prerequisites: One of DRAMA 206, 207, 306, 307, 316, 317; Theatre and Performance students only.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Theatre Criticism
data.description: Study and practice of the criticism of theatre production and performance.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A Theatre and Performance or Speech Communication majors in the Performance Studies area of concentration only
data.notes: [Note: May be subject to priority enrolment. There is a course fee of $150 to pay for the cost of theatre tickets and transportation to and from theatres.]

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Theatre Technology and Management Apprenticeship 1
data.description: An advanced course. Selected students are apprenticed in theatre technology or management functions in productions both on and off campus.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Advanced Acting Workshop 1
data.description: An intensive workshop designed to develop performance skills. Special attention given to individual acting problems.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Advanced Acting Workshop 2
data.description: An extension of DRAMA 421.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Audition Technique and Professional Orientation
data.description: An intensive approach to monologue work, this course will prepare students for the audition process. Time will also be devoted to learning about the demands of the theatre profession, and the problems faced by the self-employed artist.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Advanced Voice Technique
data.description: An advanced workshop course in voice for the actor and speaker designed to continue the exploration of voice technique in DRAMA/SPCOM 326.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Performative Inquiry and Practice
data.description: This course explores how to create, perform and analyze performance texts, here defined as including drama/theatre texts, poetry, narratives, and the texts of everyday life. Through readings and creative investigation, students will explore the links between the participant, the researcher, the site and the impulse of inquiry.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Selected Seminars in Drama & Theatre Arts
data.description: Seminars in special areas of drama and theatre.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Selected Seminars in Drama & Theatre Arts
data.description: Seminars in special areas of drama and theatre.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Senior Seminar
data.description: This course is designed to give the student an opportunity to complete a comprehensive presentation in her/his major area of concentration.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A Honours Theatre and Performance
data.notes: [Note: A grade for DRAMA/SPCOM 499A will be submitted only after the completion of DRAMA/SPCOM 499B.]

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Senior Seminar
data.description: This course is designed to give the student an opportunity to complete a comprehensive presentation in her/his major area of concentration. Second part of DRAMA/SPCOM 499.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A Honours Theatre and Performance

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Survey of Dramatic Literature and Theory 5
data.description: The first part of the 20th century.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Survey of Dramatic Literature and Theory 6
data.description: The second part of the 20th century.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Canadian Drama
data.description: This course explores traditions and experiments in Canadian drama through an analysis of Canadian plays, especially those from 1960 to the present, in their historical and theatrical contexts.

data.title: English Drama to 1642
data.description: The Middle Ages, the Elizabethans and Jacobeans (excluding Shakespeare), and the Spanish Golden Age.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Shakespeare 1
data.description: A study of the plays written before 1599-1600, excluding Julius Caesar.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Shakespeare 2
data.description: A study of the plays written after 1599-1600, including Julius Caesar.

data.notes: [Note: Taught in English. This course will have a Slavic language component for students in REES academic plans.]

data.title: Russian Drama after 1905
data.description: A study of the origins and development of Russian drama after 1905. Reading and critical analysis of major works in various genres with emphasis on authors of the 20th century.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English. This course will have a Slavic language component for students in REES academic plans.]

data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A Honours Theatre and Performance
data.notes: [Note: A grade for DRAMA/SPCOM 499A will be submitted only after the completion of DRAMA/SPCOM 499B.]

data.description: This course is designed to give the student an opportunity to complete a comprehensive presentation in her/his major area of concentration. Second part of DRAMA/SPCOM 499.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A Honours Theatre and Performance

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Survey of Dramatic Literature and Theory 3
data.description: French Neo-Classicism, the Restoration Period and Sentimental Drama.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Survey of Dramatic Literature and Theory 4
data.description: The late 18th and 19th centuries; romanticism and naturalism.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Production Participation 6
data.description: Students work at an intermediate level with faculty, staff, and visiting artists to explore and increase proficiency through extensive contributions to specific areas of performance creation. Areas include research, conception, writing, direction, design, performance, production, stage management, production management, publicity, dramaturgy, critique, and documentation.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: William Shakespeare in Performance
data.description: This course focuses on a major dramatist. It will consider first of all the times, the life and the work. It will then concentrate on productions of plays in various media, and include interpretations, design styles, critical reception and related topics.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Anton Chekhov in Performance
data.description: This course focuses on a major dramatist. It will consider first of all the times, the life and the work. It will then concentrate on productions of plays in various media, and include interpretations, design styles, critical reception and related topics.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Stephen Sondheim in Performance
data.description: This course focuses on a major dramatist. It will consider first of all the times, the life and the work. It will then concentrate on productions of plays in various media, and include interpretations, design styles, critical reception and related topics.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Design for the Theatre 2
data.description: An extension of the studies described in DRAMA 331, concentrating on the practicalities of set design.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Scenic Painting
data.description: Decorative painting has been part of worldwide culture since at least the Paleolithic Age. For the past four hundred years, scenic painting has been central to theatre production. This practical course examines the history, techniques and methods of this unique and ephemeral art, blending practical exercises with research work.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A Drama or Fine Arts students

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Cultural Management 1
data.description: An introduction to the problems and techniques of contemporary not-for-profit cultural management. Topics include: budgeting and financial control, marketing and board/management relations.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Cultural Management 2
data.description: An advanced course which focuses on current and emerging issues in cultural management and policy.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Cultural Management 3
data.description: An advanced course in management and development in the not-for-profit sector. Topics include: the context of philanthropy in Canada, understanding organizational culture and the role of the not-for-profit board in fundraising.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: The Cinema of Science Fiction
data.description: A chronological survey of one of the most intriguing of film genres. Discussion of its aesthetic, philosophical and cinematic aspects. Film screenings will present major international works in this genre (Godard, Kubrick, Lang, Marker, Siegel, Tarkovsky, Truffaut and other directors). Film screenings.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Contemporary Italian Film
data.description: A study of major achievements of the Italian cinema in its post- Neo-Realist period. Discussion of the works of major directors since the late 1950s (Antonioni, Bertolucci, Fellini, Olmi, Taviani, Rosi, Visconti and others). Film screenings.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: New Cinemas of East Asia (from 1985)
data.description: This course examines the role of the post-1985 East-Asian film in the development of motion picture art and the East-West cultural exchange, focusing on Chinese (Mainland China, Hong Kong, Taiwan) and Korean cinemas. It will assist students in interpreting non-Western modes of cinematic expression. Screenings and seminar discussions will include a selection from the fifth and sixth generations of Chinese filmmakers: Hong Kong's auteur Wong Kar Wai; Taiwanese directors Hou Hsiao-hsien and Tsai Ming-liang; the achievements of Korea's master filmmaker Im Kwon-taek, and the newcomer Kim Ki-duk.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: History of Animated Film
data.description: This course will examine the historical development of the animated film and the diversity of its stylistic expression. It will focus on some of the most significant achievements of the animated form in an international context, including: Early film animation; Disney and Hollywood cartoon; two and three dimensional and live action animation in Western Europe; Czech animation; the Zagreb animation school, and the Russian animation; National Film Board of Canada and the independent US animation; Japanese tradition; recent advances in computer and experimental animation.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: History of Film 1 (1895-1940)
data.description: History of world cinema in its silent and early sound era, covering the work of outstanding directors, national productions and movements, and their contribution to the film medium's development into a prominent art form of the 20th century. Film screenings.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: History of Film 2 (after 1941)
data.description: A continuation of FINE 250/DRAMA 356. From the beginnings of the modern sound cinema (Welles) to the contemporary period. Film screenings.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: French Film After 1945
data.description: A study of major achievements of the French cinema after World War II. Discussion and comparison of the two main creative impulses of the period: the Academic tradition of the 40s and 50s, and the rebellious nouvelle vague of the 60s. (Bresson, Carne, Ophuls, Renoir, Chabrol, Godard, Malle, Truffaut, Resnais, and others.) Film screenings.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Theatre for Young Audiences
data.description: Principles, methods, forms and styles of theatre for children. Children's theatre play-scripts examined and evaluated in a workshop situation.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Women in the Theatre
data.description: A study of some of the most important female theatre artists and the diverse ways in which they have brought a female sensibility to the art form at different stages in theatre history. The course will also touch upon the issue of gender representation in theatrical production and sexual politics in the theatre.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Plays on Film
data.description: The course examines the relationship between stage and film. A number of play scripts and their film adaptations are examined, concentrating on how a filmmaker manipulates stage text to create a film text.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Modern British Film
data.description: The course examines British film as a political expression of the changing British class system, from pre-war and interwar expressions of the social classes in films such as CAVALCADE and BRIEF ENCOUNTER, through the swift changes of the 1950s and early 1960s in films by Reisz, Richardson and Anderson, and the swinging London of the mid-to-late 1960s, up to the present day. The course focuses on the way the films parallel British social and political change.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Survey of Dramatic Literature and Theory 3
data.description: French Neo-Classicism, the Restoration Period and Sentimental Drama.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Survey of Dramatic Literature and Theory 4
data.description: The late 18th and 19th centuries; romanticism and naturalism.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: History of Film 1 (1895-1940)
data.description: History of world cinema in its silent and early sound era, covering the work of outstanding directors, national productions and movements, and their contribution to the film medium's development into a prominent art form of the 20th century. Film screenings.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: History of Film 2 (after 1941)
data.description: A continuation of FINE 250/DRAMA 356. From the beginnings of the modern sound cinema (Welles) to the contemporary period. Film screenings.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Scenic Painting
data.description: Decorative painting has been part of worldwide culture since at least the Paleolithic Age. For the past four hundred years, scenic painting has been central to theatre production. This practical course examines the history, techniques and methods of this unique and ephemeral art, blending practical exercises with research work.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A Drama or Fine Arts students

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Design for the Theatre 2
data.description: An extension of the studies described in DRAMA 331, concentrating on the practicalities of set design.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: French Film After 1945
data.description: A study of major achievements of the French cinema after World War II. Discussion and comparison of the two main creative impulses of the period: the Academic tradition of the 40s and 50s, and the rebellious nouvelle vague of the 60s. (Bresson, Carne, Ophuls, Renoir, Chabrol, Godard, Malle, Truffaut, Resnais, and others.) Film screenings.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: The Cinema of Science Fiction
data.description: A chronological survey of one of the most intriguing of film genres. Discussion of its aesthetic, philosophical and cinematic aspects. Film screenings will present major international works in this genre (Godard, Kubrick, Lang, Marker, Siegel, Tarkovsky, Truffaut and other directors). Film screenings.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Contemporary Italian Film
data.description: A study of major achievements of the Italian cinema in its post- Neo-Realist period. Discussion of the works of major directors since the late 1950s (Antonioni, Bertolucci, Fellini, Olmi, Taviani, Rosi, Visconti and others). Film screenings.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: New Cinemas of East Asia (from 1985)
data.description: This course examines the role of the post-1985 East-Asian film in the development of motion picture art and the East-West cultural exchange, focusing on Chinese (Mainland China, Hong Kong, Taiwan) and Korean cinemas. It will assist students in interpreting non-Western modes of cinematic expression. Screenings and seminar discussions will include a selection from the fifth and sixth generations of Chinese filmmakers: Hong Kong's auteur Wong Kar Wai; Taiwanese directors Hou Hsiao-hsien and Tsai Ming-liang; the achievements of Korea's master filmmaker Im Kwon-taek, and the newcomer Kim Ki-duk.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: History of Animated Film
data.description: This course will examine the historical development of the animated film and the diversity of its stylistic expression. It will focus on some of the most significant achievements of the animated form in an international context, including: Early film animation; Disney and Hollywood cartoon; two and three dimensional and live action animation in Western Europe; Czech animation; the Zagreb animation school, and the Russian animation; National Film Board of Canada and the independent US animation; Japanese tradition; recent advances in computer and experimental animation.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Plays on Film
data.description: The course examines the relationship between stage and film. A number of play scripts and their film adaptations are examined, concentrating on how a filmmaker manipulates stage text to create a film text.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Modern British Film
data.description: The course examines British film as a political expression of the changing British class system, from pre-war and interwar expressions of the social classes in films such as CAVALCADE and BRIEF ENCOUNTER, through the swift changes of the 1950s and early 1960s in films by Reisz, Richardson and Anderson, and the swinging London of the mid-to-late 1960s, up to the present day. The course focuses on the way the films parallel British social and political change.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Cultural Management 1
data.description: An introduction to the problems and techniques of contemporary not-for-profit cultural management. Topics include: budgeting and financial control, marketing and board/management relations.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Advanced Voice Technique
data.description: An advanced workshop course in voice for the actor and speaker designed to continue the exploration of voice technique in DRAMA/SPCOM 326.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Introduction to the Theatre 2
data.description: An extension of the studies described in 101A.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Production Participation 1
data.description: Students work with faculty, staff, and visiting artists to explore and develop basic proficiency in specific areas of performance creation. Areas include research, conception, writing, direction, design, performance, production, stage management, production management, publicity, dramaturgy, critique, and documentation.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Production Participation 2
data.description: Students work with faculty, staff, and visiting artists to explore and develop basic proficiency in specific areas of performance creation. Areas include research, conception, writing, direction, design, performance, production, stage management, production management, publicity, dramaturgy, critique, and documentation.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Design for Performance
data.description: Students explore historical and current perspectives on the principles of design for performance.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Management for the Arts
data.description: Students explore a broad range of arts management concepts. Assignments take students' individual interests into account.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Theatre and the New Media
data.description: The primary objective of this course is to investigate ways in which new media technologies have been, and can be, applied in theatrical practice. It examines the range of opportunities and challenges this synthesis poses and provides students with some of the insights and skills required to apply new media technologies in a theatrical context. On the basis of such practical and theoretical study, students will also engage in projects which explore creatively the coalition between theatre and the new media.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Theatre and Performance in Canada
data.description: Students explore theatre and performance in Canada in its historical, political, and cultural contexts.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Gender and Performance
data.description: Students explore representations of gender on stage, in the media, and in politics.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Site-Specific Performance
data.description: Students explore performance sites as resources for creation.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Early English Theatre
data.description: Students explore the early development and continuing relevance of English language theatre and performance practices.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Language, Theatre, and Performance
data.description: Students explore the relationship between language and meaning in historical and contemporary theatre and performance.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Theories of Theatre and Performance
data.description: Students study and critique a range of existing works of theatre and performance in the context of related commentary, paying close attention to concepts of knowledge, experience, and positionality.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Production Participation 5
data.description: Students work at an intermediate level with faculty, staff, and visiting artists to explore and increase proficiency through extensive contributions to specific areas of performance creation. Areas include research, conception, writing, direction, design, performance, production, stage management, production management, publicity, dramaturgy, critique, and documentation.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Collaborative Creation
data.description: Students explore techniques for collaborative creation in theatre and performance.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Sustainability in Performance
data.description: Students explore the interchange between artistic practice and current topics in sustainability research.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Political Theatre
data.description: Considers the politics of governing, religion, family, marriage, work, race, gender and sexual orientation as they are expressed and commented on in a variety of contemporary, international play texts. Class discussion focuses on both the texts and the society that gave rise to each playwright's passions.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Black Theatre and Performance
data.description: Students explore the relationship of black theatre and performance to artistic and public life in North America.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Virtual Theatre and Performance
data.description: Students explore and create theatre and performance in virtual reality.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Collaborative Performance Project
data.description: Students work at an advanced, independent level with faculty, staff, and visiting artists to create and reflect upon a major, collaborative performance project. As core members of the creative team, students engage in all areas of project creation, including research, conception, writing, direction, design, performance, production, stage management, production management, publicity, dramaturgy, critique, and documentation.
data.prerequisites: One of DRAMA 206, 207, 306, 307, 316, 317; Theatre and Performance students only.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Collaborative Performance Project
data.description: Students work at an advanced, independent level with faculty, staff, and visiting artists to create and reflect upon a major, collaborative performance project. As core members of the creative team, students engage in all areas of project creation, including research, conception, writing, direction, design, performance, production, stage management, production management, publicity, dramaturgy, critique, and documentation.
data.prerequisites: One of DRAMA 206, 207, 306, 307, 316, 317; Theatre and Performance students only.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Production Participation 9
data.description: Students work at an advanced, independent level with faculty, staff, and visiting artists to create and reflect upon a major, collaborative performance project. Through extensive contributions to production, students engage in all areas of project creation, including research, conception, writing, direction, design, performance, production, stage management, production management, publicity, dramaturgy, critique, and documentation.
data.prerequisites: One of DRAMA 206, 207, 306, 307, 316, 317; Theatre and Performance students only.

data.subject: DRAMA
data.title: Production Participation 10
data.description: Students work at an advanced, independent level with faculty, staff, and visiting artists to create and reflect upon a major, collaborative performance project. Through extensive contributions to production, students engage in all areas of project creation, including research, conception, writing, direction, design, performance, production, stage management, production management, publicity, dramaturgy, critique, and documentation.
data.prerequisites: One of DRAMA 206, 207, 306, 307, 316, 317; Theatre and Performance students only.
